<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 291]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 376, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 100.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 625, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 101, 616, 120]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 556, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\] \[\nu^2 = u^2 +2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 520, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 193, 532, 222]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 235, 520, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 262, 556, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 304, 536, 320]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 339, 601, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{v\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 425, 536, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 468, 623, 487]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 500, 593, 519]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 530, 520, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 570, 526, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 593, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 637, 623, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 512, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 715, 556, 733]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 747, 576, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 777, 532, 811]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 89]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 118, 96, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 148, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 479, 137]]<|/det|>
Define gravitational potential at a point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 240, 146, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 240, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
The Earth may be considered to be a uniform sphere of radius \(6.4 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\) with its mass of \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\) concentrated at its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
A satellite of mass \(2.4 \times 10^{3} \text{kg}\) is launched from the Equator. It is placed in an equatorial orbit at a height of \(5.6 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\) above the Earth's surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 181, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
Calculate the change \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\) in gravitational potential energy of the satellite for its movement from the surface of the Earth to its position in the equatorial orbit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}} =\) .................................................... J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 599, 181, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 599, 604, 616]]<|/det|>
Determine the speed of the satellite when in orbit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 816, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 816, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Before the satellite in **(b)** is launched, its speed at the Equator due to the Earth's rotation is \(470 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 918, 149]]<|/det|>
Suggest why the energy required to launch the satellite depends on whether the satellite, in its orbit, is travelling from west to east or from east to west.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 210, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 611, 91]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the internal energy of a system.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
The atoms of an ideal gas occupy a container of volume \(2.30 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\) at pressure \(2.60 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and temperature \(180 \text{K}\), as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 386, 532, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
The gas is heated at constant pressure so that its volume becomes \(3.80 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\) at a temperature \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 457, 483]]<|/det|>
For the fixed mass of gas, calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 496, 181, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

the amount of substance, in mol

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 680, 920, 697]]<|/det|>

the temperature \(T\), in K.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 894, 920, 912]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... K [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 756, 91]]<|/det|>
During the change in **(b)**, the thermal energy supplied to the gas is 980 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 181, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 101, 839, 121]]<|/det|>
Determine the work done on the gas during this change. Explain your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 286, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 317, 181, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 500, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\Delta U =\) .................................................... J [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
A simple pendulum consists of a metal sphere suspended from a fixed point by means of a thread, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 116, 725, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 359, 591, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 920, 424]]<|/det|>
The sphere of mass \(94.0 \text{g}\) is displaced to one side through a horizontal distance of \(12.7 \text{cm}\). The centre of gravity of the sphere rises vertically by \(0.90 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 437, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
The sphere is released so that it oscillates. The sphere may be assumed to oscillate with simple harmonic motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 483, 144, 501]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 483, 554, 501]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by simple harmonic motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 605, 144, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 605, 175, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 605, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
State the kinetic energy of the sphere when the sphere returns to the displaced position shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 651, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .................................................... J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 682, 180, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 682, 586, 700]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total energy \(E_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 867, 920, 886]]<|/det|>
<form>E_{\mathrm{T}} = ............................................................ J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 868, 920, 886]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (ii) to show that the angular frequency \(\omega\) of the oscillations of the pendulum is \(3.3 \text{rad} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 144, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 303, 728, 322]]<|/det|>
The period \(T\) of oscillation of the pendulum is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 330, 551, 369]]<|/det|>
\[T = 2\pi \sqrt{\left(\frac{L}{g}\right)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 384, 767, 403]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall and \(L\) is the length of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 416, 433, 435]]<|/det|>
Use data from **(b)** to determine \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 599, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 870, 89]]<|/det|>
State two advantages of the transmission of data in digital, rather than analogue, form.

1. ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 917, 180]]<|/det|>
2. ....................................................................................................................................................

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 599, 260]]<|/det|>
An analogue signal is to be transmitted in digital form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 761, 291]]<|/det|>
The transmission system may be represented in block form as in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 301, 917, 386]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 402, 532, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 434, 813, 453]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of part of the input analogue signal is shown in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 464, 806, 744]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 772, 532, 790]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 803, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
The analogue signal is sampled at time intervals of \(0.10\mathrm{ms}\). The first sample is taken at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 850, 920, 883]]<|/det|>
Some values of the sampled analogue signal and the corresponding digital signals are shown in Table 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 897, 492, 914]]<|/det|>
Each digitised number contains four bits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 42, 510, 58]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 102, 922, 259]]<|/det|>
time \(t/\mathrm{ms}\)00.100.200.300.400.50
analogue signal
/mV		05.76.2.........................................................
digital signal000001010110.........................................................
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 275, 180, 293]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 275, 920, 310]]<|/det|> In Table 4.1, underline the least significant bit (LSB) in the digital signal for the time of 0.20 ms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 920, 316]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 316, 180, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 316, 363, 335]]<|/det|> Complete Table 4.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 335]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 146, 365]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 920, 381]]<|/det|> A single bit from the output of the digital-to-analogue converter corresponds to an output analogue signal of 1.0 mV. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 393, 781, 411]]<|/det|> Assume that the conversion and transmission do not introduce a time delay. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 424, 920, 457]]<|/det|> On the axes of Fig. 4.3, show the variation with time \(t\) of the output from the digital-to-analogue converter. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 468, 806, 747]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 765, 534, 784]]<|/det|> Fig. 4.3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 781, 920, 799]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 812, 920, 829]]<|/det|> [Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 912, 89]]<|/det|>
the electric field strength at point P, a distance \(x = 0.45 \text{m}\) from the centre of the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 255, 920, 273]]<|/det|>
<form>electric field strength = ............................................. $\text{V} \text{m}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 256, 920, 274]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 144, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 286, 920, 319]]<|/det|>
Use information from **(b)** to show, on the axes of Fig. 5.2, the variation of the electric field strength \(E\) with distance \(x\) from the centre of the sphere for values of \(x\) from \(x = 0\) to \(x = 0.45 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 330, 794, 712]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 728, 534, 746]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 618, 337]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 348, 606, 373]]<|/det|>
\[{}_{26}^{56}\mathrm {Fe}+{}_{9}^{10}\mathrm {n}\rightarrow {}_{9}^{20}\mathrm {F}+{}_{17}^{37}\mathrm {Cl}.\]
